text: Okay. So options are convex with respect to many things. The most two important are as the market level itself, as the spot market moves around, and then as the implied volatility changes. And of course, those exposures are dynamic in how close to the money the options are. So when the options are exactly at the money, or technically they're at the money forward, all those risks are the greatest. So when you buy an out of the money option, as the market goes down, both your exposure with respect to spot and your exposure with respect to ball are getting larger. So the question is, which one of these are you going to pull on to generate value in your strategy? And the just absolute conclusive fact of equity index options since the financial crisis is that implied volatility has not performed outside of... Some very, very small windows. So after the financial crisis in 2011, you had the European sovereign debt crisis, vol did perform there. But then after that, there have been spikes, but they would have been very, very hard to monetize. COVID is such an excellent example. It's easy to look at the chart now and go, whoa, I could have made a lot of money if I owned some options in January and sold them on this day that I pick. But when you're standing in the middle of it, those monetization decisions are very, very high. And it's very easy to miss them. People try to deal with this by setting up rules like, for every X shift, I'm going to sell X percent of my exposure. I think it's a professional way to do it. And I get it. But monetizing that stuff is really challenging, and particularly as the windows get shorter. Now, I think there's good structural reasons why that dynamic has persisted since the financial crisis. And it's a combination of we've had very accommodative monetary policy, but much less monetary policy. And I think that's a good way to do it. And I think that's a good way to do it. And I think that's a good way to do it. And I think that's a good way more importantly, the regulatory regime has changed. The landscape of people that can take and warehouse risk has changed a lot. It used to be when I started at the bank, there was no CCAR on the Fed. There was no Basel. There was no Dodd-Frank. There was no one sending us a spreadsheet of balance sheet charges. None of that stuff existed. So fast forward to 2020, and now the risk limits are much, much different. There's a lot more stress testing. The entire market knows about and is paying attention to the stress test. So the landscape for insurance guys has changed a lot, too. So the need, essentially, or the ability for vol to expand a lot in these downturns, we just think is a lot less. Because you're starting from, there's less marginal actors that have to run out and quickly cover risk on even a down 20% move. So a lot of this risk has just been regulated out to different players. And I'm not sure that that's a bad thing. You said before, you can't destroy risk, you can only transfer it. I mean, the way that derivatives, at the end of the day, are a risk transfer tool that should be used to spread risk from someone that doesn't want it to someone who's willing to bear it for a fair price. So to some extent, the fact that we haven't had major vol-expeditions, we haven't had major expansion in the last decade plus, is a sign, I think, that that process is probably healthier than it was beforehand. But it doesn't help you if you're running a risk mitigating strategy, and you're trying to access that as a lever of value. What does work and what has worked is convexity with respect to spot. It worked last year. And as long as the market itself is volatile, it will continue to work. Low realized volatility solves aren't possible. Though less likely. But the implication for the manager, again, is a lot more rebalancing. It's a much more active strategy to run a gamma strategy or a convexity with respect to stock strategy requires you to trade more, have more trading infrastructure, and put stress on all the stuff that we've been talking about as you add more trades to an SMA platform that's allocating across many accounts with many custodians. So you have to use technology to fix it. But again, this is another implication of how your operational environment and the way that you deliver the product has an important feedback loop into the investment opportunity set and the investment advocacy that the manager is able to deliver. So we think that based on both the supply and demand and behavior of implied volatility, really since the financial crisis, and combined with a different regulatory environment, we think convexity with respect to spot is the better lever of value for now. Could that change? If we went through a big deregulation cycle and a slightly different monetary policy regime, could that change? Sure. And we'll have to adapt if it does. But for now, we think this is the way to go.
